citation.article-title: Lactobacillus mucosae sp. nov., a new species with in vitro mucus-binding activity isolated from pig intestine.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus mucosae sp. nov.
Lactobacillus mucosae (mu'co.sae. L. gen. n. mucosae of mucosa)
Cells are Gram-positive, non-motile, non-sporeforming, catalase-negative rods with dimensions of 1x2-4 μm.
The cells occur singly, in pairs or as short chains and have an Orn-D-Asp peptidoglycan type.
After anaerobic growth at 37 °C for 2 d, colonies on MRS agar are 1-2 mm in diameter.
They are white, smooth and convex.
The cells are obligately heterofermentative and produce D- and L-lactic acid.
They grow at 45 °C but not at 15 °C.
Acid is produced from glucose, ribose, maltose and saccharose.
The majority of strains also ferment D-xylose, melibiose, D-raffinose and gluconate.
L-Arabinose, galactose or lactose may be utilized by some strains.

D-Fructose, glycerol, erythritol, L-xylose, adonitol, D-mannose, L-sorbose, rhamnose, dulcitol, inositol, mannitol, sorbitol, methyl α-D-glucoside, N-acetylglucosamine, salicine, cellobiose, trehalose, inuline, melizitose, amidon, glycogen, xylitol, D-turanose, D-lyxose, D-taganose, D-fucose, L-fucose, D-arabitol, 2-keto-gluconate and 5-ketogluconate are not utilized.
The DNA G­C content of strain S32T is 46.5±0.2 mol%.
All strains of this species so far described have a homologue to the mucus-binding protein, Mub, and exhibit mucus-binding ability in vitro.
